meta.content: Direct Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide from Hydrogen and Oxygen Using Tailored Pd Nanocatalysts: A Review of Recent Findings
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Catalysis Surveys from Asia 2016 21:1
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2016 Springer Science+Business Media New York
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen is being actively studied as an alternative to the current manufacturing process. The direct synthesis route has not reached the point of commercialization because of low yields, but significant effort is being spent on enhancing the productivity. With advances in computational capacity, simulation studies based on DFT calculations now offer directions for catalyst improvement, but such modifications can only be realized through the application of nanoparticle synthesis techniques that allow for nanocrystal morphology and size control and unique immobilization. To date, there have only been a small number of studies on such nanoparticles with size and crystallographic homogeneity for the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. According to our knowledge no other group has systematically investigated application of nanoparticles in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and thus included in this review are primarily previous studies conducted by our group. In this review, we discuss the utilization of nanotechnology for the synthesis of Pd catalysts and its effect on the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and we suggest a direction for future studies.

meta.content: Direct Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide from Hydrogen and Oxygen Using Tailored Pd Nanocatalysts: A Review of Recent Findings - Catalysis Surveys from Asia

Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen is being actively studied as an alternative to the current manufacturing process. The direct synthesis route has not reached the point of commercialization because of low yields, but significant effort is being spent on enhancing the productivity. With advances in computational capacity, simulation studies based on DFT calculations now offer directions for catalyst improvement, but such modifications can only be realized through the application of nanoparticle synthesis techniques that allow for nanocrystal morphology and size control and unique immobilization. To date, there have only been a small number of studies on such nanoparticles with size and crystallographic homogeneity for the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. According to our knowledge no other group has systematically investigated application of nanoparticles in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and thus included in this review are primarily previous studies conducted by our group. In this review, we discuss the utilization of nanotechnology for the synthesis of Pd catalysts and its effect on the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and we suggest a direction for future studies.

div.div: Direct Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide from Hydrogen and Oxygen Using Tailored Pd Nanocatalysts: A Review of Recent Findings

header.h1: Direct Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide from Hydrogen and Oxygen Using Tailored Pd Nanocatalysts: A Review of Recent Findings
header.p:
Catalysis Surveys from Asia
volume
21
,
pages
1–12 (
2017
)
Cite this article

li.p:
1527

div.p: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen is being actively studied as an alternative to the current manufacturing process. The direct synthesis route has not reached the point of commercialization because of low yields, but significant effort is being spent on enhancing the productivity. With advances in computational capacity, simulation studies based on DFT calculations now offer directions for catalyst improvement, but such modifications can only be realized through the application of nanoparticle synthesis techniques that allow for nanocrystal morphology and size control and unique immobilization. To date, there have only been a small number of studies on such nanoparticles with size and crystallographic homogeneity for the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. According to our knowledge no other group has systematically investigated application of nanoparticles in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and thus included in this review are primarily previous studies conducted by our group. In this review, we discuss the utilization of nanotechnology for the synthesis of Pd catalysts and its effect on the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, and we suggest a direction for future studies.

Hydrogen peroxide decomposes into oxygen and water and is a powerful, environmentally friendly oxidant that is used as a bleaching or oxidizing agent in various industries including pulp and paper industries, electronics, wastewater treatment, and mining [
1
–
4
]. It is also extensively used in the synthesis of high-value chemicals such as cyclohexanoxime, hydroquinone, and propylene oxide [
5
–
9
]. Owing to its attractive characteristics such as versatility and environmental friendliness, industrial hydrogen peroxide consumption is expected to grow annually by 3.8 % on average, and the demand is forecasted to reach 5.2 million metric tons by 2020 [
10
]. Today, hydrogen peroxide is produced almost exclusively by an autoxidation (AO) process involving consecutive hydrogenation and oxidation of anthraquinone [
11
]. However, the operating costs are high because of the multi-step setup, which necessitates large-scale, off-site hydrogen peroxide manufacturing. Additional transportation and on-site purification of the product are also required, as the product must be diluted to 2–8 wt% for safe transportation (in the absence of a stabilizing agent) [
11
,
12
]. Several methods have been studied as an alternative to the anthraquinone process, and they include electrochemical synthesis using a fuel cell system and plasma-assisted synthesis [
13
–
15
]. However, such technologies have received little attention as they are difficult to scale up commercially.

A direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen has drawn attention as an attractive alternative [
16
–
25
]. Reactions that take place in the direct route and the corresponding enthalpies and Gibbs free energies are listed in Scheme
1
[
26
]. The direct synthesis route presents several advantages over the AO process: (i) environmentally favorable nature: the only byproduct is water (and oxygen), and the need for a toxic organic solvent is obviated; (ii) cheap operating cost: There is no need for an expensive organic solvent system; (iii) on-site manufacturing: this synthesis route would allow small-scale, on-site production of hydrogen peroxide [
27
–
31
]. An example of on-site manufacturing is the direct synthesis process of hydrogen peroxide–hydrogen peroxide propylene oxide (DSHP–HPPO) proposed by BASF, as depicted in Scheme
2
[
31
]. Propylene and hydrogen are formed via dehydrogenation of propane, and the produced hydrogen is fed to the direct hydrogen peroxide reactor along with oxygen. Intermediate products, propylene and hydrogen peroxide, are consumed to yield the final propylene oxide product. This setup can minimize the operating cost of propylene oxide manufacturing plants because the output stream from the hydrogen peroxide formation column can be directly fed into the propylene oxide column without a need for separation/purification. However, this process is accompanied by several shortcomings that prevent commercialization: (i) low selectivity: the same metals (Pd- and Pt-based bulk or alloys) that catalyze hydrogen peroxide formation (Scheme
1
—reaction I) are also excellent catalysts for the subsequent decomposition reactions of the desired product (Scheme
1
—reaction III and IV) and parallel water formation (Scheme
1
—reaction II); (ii) low productivity: because the synthesis is a three-phase reaction, the overall mass transfer of reactants is kinetically limiting and a certain degree of productivity compromise is inevitable; (iii) explosive nature of the reactants: due to the explosiveness of the reactant mixture over a large range of the hydrogen concentrations, reactions are performed in the liquid phase [
32
–
36
]. While the explosion risk can be managed with high dilution of the hydrogen with inert gas, achieving high selectivity and productivity remains a major challenge in commercialization of the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis.
Reaction pathways related to the direct formation of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen

Through years of research from various groups, several major factors affecting the overall productivity/selectivity of Pd catalysts have been identified [
17
,
23
,
29
,
33
,
37
–
41
]. Owing to the development of computational capacity, DFT simulations are vigorously utilized to study the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. DFT calculations can predict the adsorption energies of hydrogen and oxygen on different facets of crystalline Pd and the activation energies of the intermediate reaction steps to simulate the synthesis reaction [
25
,
42
–
45
]. However, DFT simulations assume a solvent-free system in vacuum at 0 K. Therefore, DFT simulations must be complemented by experimental data. Achieving a singular morphology has proven to be difficult, if not impossible, using general catalyst preparation techniques such as the incipient wetness method—in which metal precursors are adsorbed on the support and reduced by chemical and thermal treatments—making the use of novel methods necessary. Several methods for enabling selective surface exposure of synthesized nanoparticles have been reported, and the as-synthesized nanoparticles have been considerable improvements to those without selective morphology. Several review papers that discuss Pd-based catalysts (including those with morphology- (or shape-) and size-control) have been published [
12
,
46
–
48
], but there is no review detailing of those Pd nanoparticles for their application specifically to direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis.

In this focused review, we specifically discuss the effects of the Pd nanoparticle morphology, size, and support structure on direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. The catalytic activity of Pd nanoparticles are significantly affected by their shape. The effects of acid (homogeneous or heterogeneous) and halide ion additives are also discussed herein. Lastly, the Pd nanoparticle encapsulation techniques and encapsulation influence on the catalytic performance will be discussed.

section.data-title: Reaction mechanism of the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis

div.h2: Reaction mechanism of the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis

div.p:
Despite the simplicity of the hydrogen peroxide formation, the overall process is complicated by undesirable side reactions of water formation and subsequent hydrogen peroxide hydrogenation and decomposition. Precise knowledge of the reaction mechanism is crucial for effective, systematic studies and application of the catalyst. An important factor that determines the hydrogen peroxide selectivity is whether or not the reactant oxygen is undissociatively adsorbed on the Pd surface and follows the hydrogen peroxide formation path. A detailed description for the reaction mechanism of direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis is as follows [
25
,
30
,
42
,
43
,
49
].

li.p:
Synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (Scheme
1
—reaction I)
(* denotes a surface site).
Adsorbed molecular oxygen is consecutively hydrogenated to an OOH intermediate and the final product, HOOH, before being desorbed.

Undesirable formation of water (Scheme
1
—reactions II, III, and IV)

div.p:
Reactions II, III, and IV lead to water byproduct formation and are initiated by O–O bond dissociation in oxygen, the OOH intermediate, and hydrogen peroxide, respectively. Dissociative adsorption of molecular oxidation yields atomic oxygen species, which are converted to hydroxyl (OH) intermediates upon hydrogenation. The OH intermediate is either hydrogenated to water (OH* + H* → H
2
O*) or disproportionates to water and atomic oxygen (OH* + OH* → H
2
O* + O*). Peroxy species (OOH and HOOH) can dissociate to hydroxyl intermediates, leading to hydrogenation or disproportionation.

In general, the pertinent reaction parameters can be optimized to help overcome the yield barrier of the direct approach. Increasing the solubility of the gaseous reactants in the reaction solvent facilitates their adsorption on the catalyst surface and the reaction, and has proven quite effective. Low-temperature and high-pressure operation in a solvent with high solvation power (often methanol, ethanol, or water/organic solvent mixture) is thus preferred [
28
,
50
]. Pressurizing the reactor in particular has proven to be effective in enhancing the hydrogen peroxide yield. Menegazzo et al. demonstrated that increasing the reaction pressure from 1 to 10 bar boosted the hydrogen peroxide production rate by more than one order of magnitude without notable change in the selectivity [
28
]. Addition of acids and halide ions has also proven to be effective in enhancing product selectivity, and the combined use of both promoters is known to yield a synergistic effect. The effects of the acid and halide additives as promoters are discussed more in depth later in this paper. Recently, concepts for liquid or super critical CO
2
as medium for the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis, with the benefits of high solubility and environmental friendliness, have been proposed [
48
]. These yield-enhancing parametric optimizations, while indispensable for the development of an efficient direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis process, do not increase the selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide exception of the acid and halide promoters.

section.data-title: Effect of Pd nanocatalyst structure on the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis

div.h2: Effect of Pd nanocatalyst structure on the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis

div.p: Development of a catalyst highly selective toward hydrogen peroxide in the direct route has remained a tough challenge to catalyst chemists and engineers. With the advent of nanotechnology researchers have acquired powerful synthesis tools with metal catalyst shape, size and structure tunability. This chapter encompasses discussion on the effects of nanoscale modifications of Pd catalysts.

Different crystal surfaces differ in the interatomic separation among Pd atoms, which are believed to yield distinct interaction for the adsorption/desorption of aqueous species (namely O
2
, H
2
, halide ions) and selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide synthesis reaction at different facets are being investigated using DFT simulations [
25
,
42
–
45
], but it is still controversial which facet(s) is more favorable for hydrogen peroxide formation. Zhou et al. reported that the {110} facet was favorable for hydrogen peroxide formation while the {100} and {111} facets promoted unfavorable water formation [
45
]. Tian et al. reported the opposite results and stated that the Pd {111} facet promotes hydrogen peroxide formation whereas the {100} and {110} facets promote water formation [
25
]. Using a p(2 × 3) unit cell, they constructed a model of multi-layered slabs with 1/6 monolayer coverage to simulate Pd {100} and {111} surfaces, where two outermost layers of a six-layered slab and one outermost layer of a three-layered slab were allowed to relax, respectively. A spacing of 0.8 nm was set to avoid inter-slab interaction. Figure
1
shows the resulting energy diagrams for Pd {111} and {100} facet-catalyzed direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. These researchers claimed that at the Pd {100} and {110} facets there is substantial bond weakening that causes the O–O bond to stretch 0.124–0.413 nm. However, the magnitude of the bond weakening at the {111} facet is significantly smaller, and the O–O bond only stretches to 0.137 nm, accounting for the adsorption of the O–O bond and higher selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide. Only the {111} facet promotes hydrogen peroxide formation (Scheme
1
—reaction I) over its parallel side reaction (Scheme
1
—reaction II). On the {111} facet the transition state (TS) energy for the hydrogen peroxide formation route (0.58 eV; O–O hydrogenation) is lower than that for the water formation route (0.78 eV; O–O cleavage), whereas on the {100} facet, the former (0.67 eV) is significantly higher than the latter (0.16 eV).

Potential energy surfaces for the synthesis of H
2
O
2
on
a
Pd{111} and
b
Pd{100} surfaces. The main reactions and side reactions are indicated by
green
and
red
, respectively. The relative energy is given in eV [
25
]. (Color figure online)

Experimental investigations of the DFT simulations can only be realized by implementing a nanoparticle synthesis technique, because the commonly used incipient wetness method is unable to control selective crystal facet exposure and size uniformity [
51
]. A typical nanoparticle synthesis involves a colloidal solution in which the metal precursors (organometallic precursor or metal salt) are mixed with stabilizers (polymer or surfactant) and reducing agents in a solvent (polar or nonpolar) to initiate seed nucleation and propagate crystal growth. Once the Pd seeds are formed, the orientation of the crystal growth direction determines the shape (or morphology) of the Pd nanoparticles. Halide species as capping agents preferentially chemisorb onto a specific facet of the nanoparticle, and the remaining poorly passivated facets are allowed to grow relatively unhindered. Xia et al. discovered that in the absence of halide ions, thermodynamically stable Pd nanoctahedrons enclosed by {111} facets are grown [
52
,
53
]. Bromide ions added to the synthesis mixture promoted preferential crystal growth along the <111> direction to form Pd nanocubes, owing to the strong passivation of the bromide species at the {100} facets [
52
,
53
]. Lee et al. compared the hydrogen peroxide productivity and selectivity of the Pd {100} and {111} facets using silica-supported nanocubes and nanoctahedrons synthesized as such [
21
]. It was discovered that in the absence of halide promoters in the reaction medium, the nanooctahedron Pd/SiO
2
exhibited a higher hydrogen peroxide productivity (106 mmol H
2
O
2
/g
-Pd
h > 87 mmol H
2
O
2
/g
−Pd
h) and selectivity (41 > 31 %) than nanocube Pd/SiO
2
(Fig.
2
). Regardless of the controversy over the computational results, many studies are in agreement that the {111} facet has a higher catalytic activity.

(
Upper
) TEM images of Pd octahedron and Pd cube. (
Lower
) Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using Pd octahedron/SiO
2
and Pd cube/SiO
2
catalysts. Reaction conditions: T, 20 °C; P, 1 atm; time, 3 h; total flow rate, 22 mL/min; H
2
/O
2
, 1/10; reaction medium, 150 mL of DI water mixture (20 % ethanol, 0.03 M H
3
PO
4
); weight of catalyst, 0.2 g [
21
]

Pd surface active sites can be classified as either energetic (corner, edge, or defect) or less energetic (terrace) depending on the degree of unsaturation. Energetic sites are characterized by a higher degree of unsaturation and thus a higher number of dangling bonds, implying a preference for water formation and low hydrogen peroxide selectivity. Conversely, the less energetic sites with a lower degree of unsaturation would exhibit selective catalytic activity toward hydrogen peroxide formation [
28
,
32
,
40
,
54
]. It has been well established that the Pd nanoparticle size is an important factor in catalytic reactions. Generally speaking, a reduction in the Pd nanoparticle size and thus an increase in the specific Pd surface area of a reaction site are positively correlated with reactant conversion and product yield. Quite counterintuitively, however, a reduction in the nanoparticle size decreased the selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide [
22
,
23
,
28
,
55
,
56
]. For metal nanoparticles of different sizes and a uniform morphology, the numeric ratio between the numbers of the energetic and less energetic sites can be determined using the results from Hardeveld and Hartog’s study and can be correlated with the results of the catalytic reaction [
57
]. Lee et al. synthesized Pd nanocubes and nanoctahedrons of varying size and applied them to the synthesis reaction. Figure
3
shows the corresponding hydrogen conversion and hydrogen peroxide selectivity, and the relevant ratios of the energetic and less energetic sites are listed in Table
1
[
22
,
55
]. A larger Pd nanoparticle size, despite the apparent decrease in the specific surface area leading to lower hydrogen conversion, has fewer energetic sites and offers higher hydrogen peroxide selectivity.

Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using
a
Pd octahedron/SiO
2
and
b
Pd cube/SiO
2
catalysts. Reaction conditions: T, 20 °C; P, 1 atm; time, 3 h; total flow rate, 22 mL/min; H
2
/O
2
, 1/10; reaction medium, 150 mL of DI water mixture (20 % ethanol, 0.03 M H
3
PO
4
); weight of catalyst, 0.2 g [
22
,
55
]

figcaption.b:
Table 1 Number of atoms and fraction of surface atoms on Pd nanoparticles [
22
,
55
]

div.p:
Selective blocking of energetic sites on the Pd nanocatalysts during hydrogen peroxide synthesis can enhance the product selectivity. Deguchi et al. found that halide ions are more strongly adsorbed at the energetic sites, inhibiting the undesired water formation and hydrogen peroxide decomposition/hydrogenation reactions [
58
]. Many other studies reported similar, positive effects on the selectivity from adding halide ions to the hydrogen peroxide synthesis [
17
,
59
–
61
]. Many studies have reported that chloride and bromide ions are particularly beneficial for increasing the overall hydrogen peroxide yield [
16
,
17
,
59
–
61
]. Iodide ions are strongly adsorbed at the Pd catalyst surfaces and result in very low conversion of hydrogen [
46
]. Fluoride ions have been found to promote hydrogen conversion but also selectively promote undesired reactions, resulting in an insignificant change in the overall product yield [
46
]. Excessive quantities of halide ions cause blockage of the less energetic sites as well, leading to a decrease in hydrogen conversion and the net product yield.

The Lee group compared the results of hydrogen peroxide synthesis using Pd nanoctahedrons of varying sizes with bromide additives as shown in Fig.
4
[
55
]. Regardless of the presence of bromide additives, hydrogen peroxide selectivity was found to increase. However, the effect of bromide addition outweighs significantly that of the nanoparticle size. The bromide ions were selectively adsorbed at the water-forming energetic sites, thereby enhancing hydrogen peroxide selectivity. This effect was verified by demonstrating that as the ratio of energetic/less energetic sites increased, the number of bromide ions being adsorbed increased. In addition to the steric shielding effect of the energetic sites, the adsorbed halide species also alter the electronic state of the Pd atoms [
17
,
56
,
62
]. Choudhary et al. proposed a reaction mechanism where electron charges donated from the adsorbed bromide ion is transferred through the Pd to the adsorbed oxygen molecule, which in turn reacts with a proton to form a hydrogen peroxide molecule [
17
]. Generally, halide ions are added in the forms of alkali salts (e.g. KCl, KBr, NaCl, and NaBr) or acid (HCl, HBr, etc). The cations (K
+
, Na
+
, Cs
+
, etc) from the alkali salts have no effect on the hydrogen peroxide synthesis [
46
].

Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using Pd octahedron/SiO
2
catalysts. Reaction conditions: T, 20 °C; P, 1 atm; time, 3 h; total flow rate, 22 mL/min; H
2
/O
2
, 1/10; reaction medium, 150 mL of DI water mixture (20 % ethanol, 0.01 mM KBr and 0.03 M H
3
PO
4
); weight of catalyst, 0.2 g [
55
]

The stability of Pd nanoparticles is another important issue that must be addressed in order to realize sustainable operation. Loss of Pd nanoparticles after hydrogen peroxide synthesis, ranging from 25 to 77 wt%, has been reported [
21
,
22
,
63
]. Pd nanoparticles are removed from the support structure by physical detachment and/or chemical leaching. Choudhary and Samanta reported significant chemical leaching of the Pd from the catalyst structure when using phosphoric acid promoters with concentration over 0.3 M [
17
]. Chemically induced leaching was confirmed by observation of the loss of uniform morphology of Pd nanoparticles. Physical detachment of the nanoparticles, on the other hand, was confirmed by Kim et al.’s study in which the phosphoric acid with concentration below 0.3 M. Through TEM and XRD analyses, Kim et al. revealed that Pd nanoparticles had physically detached from the silica support with no evidence of chemical leaching [
21
,
22
]. In order to improve retention of the Pd nanoparticle catalysts, application of the core@shell structure is being actively studied [
23
,
26
,
37
]. The core@shell morphology offers the benefit of maintaining the core metal size at high calcination temperatures [
23
,
26
,
37
]. The core@shell structure would physically enclose the Pd nanoparticles to help prevent physical detachment and enhance stability during a reaction. A typical procedure for the core(Pd)@shell catalyst structure is shown in Scheme
3
and is described as follows: Pd nanoparticles are enclosed by an oxide shell, and during the subsequent calcination the surfactant (or polymer) is incinerated, creating pores [
23
,
26
,
37
]. There have been many substances used as an oxide shell: SiO
2
, TiO
2
, Al
2
O
3
, ZnO, SnO
2
, Cu
2
O, Fe
2
O
3
, Fe
3
O
4
and CeO
2
[
64
–
72
]. SiO
2
is a popular choice for the shell material owing to the relative ease of the synthesis, and many studies have synthesized SiO
2
shells using different variations of the famous Stöber method [
23
,
26
,
37
]. Having a low isoelectric point, SiO
2
is known to promote the hydrogen peroxide production rate [
30
]. Lee et al. demonstrated superior catalytic performance of the nanoparticles in the core@shell structure (Pd@SiO
2
, 554 mmol H
2
O
2
/g
-Pd
h) over that observed on a conventional support (Pd/SiO
2
, 267 mmol H
2
O
2
/g
-Pd
h) [
23
,
26
]. The key improvement was a significant reduction in the post-synthesis Pd loss to only 5 %.
Core@shell and yolk@shell catalysts synthesis scheme

Acids can be added to the hydrogen peroxide synthesis medium in order to enhance hydrogen peroxide selectivity. Although the role of acids has not yet been thoroughly explained, it is known to do the following: (i) promote hydrogen peroxide formation (Scheme
1
—reaction Ι); (ii) promote parallel water formation (Scheme
1
—reaction ΙΙ); (iii) inhibit hydrogen peroxide hydrogenation/decomposition by promoting desorption of the hydrogen peroxide formed at the Pd surface; (iv) promote adsorption of the halide promotors (bromide ions) at the Pd surface (in the form of H
+
–Pd–Br
−
) [
59
,
61
,
73
,
74
]. Despite the nonselective promoting behavior of the acids, an overall increase in hydrogen peroxide selectivity was observed.

Because the addition of acid can cause chemical leaching of Pd nanoparticles and corrosion of the reactor, the application of solid acid promoters to replace their liquid counterpart is currently being investigated. Song and co-workers conducted a series of studies using solid acid supports for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [
38
,
39
,
75
]. According to their findings, increasing the number of acid sites on the catalyst surface (Pd/TiO
2
–SiO
2
) was effective in improving the hydrogen peroxide yield [
75
]. Brønsted acid sites were particularly effective in promoting the reaction [
39
]. Only a small number of publications have reported the synthesis of Pd nanocatalysts in a core@shell structure with sufficient Brønsted acid sites. Seo et al. applied supported Pd nanoparticles enclosed in core@shell structure to a direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis, and the corresponding TEM images of the Pd@SiO
2
(Pd@S) and Pd@SiO
2
–Al
2
O
3
(X) (Pd@SA, X = Si/Al mole ratio: 20, 50 and 100) particles are shown in Fig.
5
[
37
]. These researchers modified a conventional Pd@SiO
2
synthesis method and developed a synthesis technique for Pd@SA (core@shell) catalysts where the shell consisted of Brønsted acidic sites. Application of these catalysts revealed that when the phosphoric acid concentration was low, the higher acid site content in the shell (lower Si/Al ratio) increased product selectivity. The presence of acids, either homogeneous (acid dissolved in the solvent) or heterogeneous (acidic sites on the catalyst), was shown to enhance hydrogen conversion and hydrogen peroxide selectivity (Fig.
6
) [
37
]. Deguchi and Iwamoto proposed a model for adsorption where the bromide ion and proton are reversibly adsorbed in pairs on the metal surface (i.e., H
+
–M–Br
−
; in our case, M = Pd) [
59
]. Seo et al. demonstrated that the acid concentration (whether in the form of the acid added to the solvent or acid sites on the catalyst surface) was positively correlated with the adsorbed bromide as shown in Fig.
7
[
37
]. Both an increase in the H
3
PO
4
concentration and the number of acid sites on the catalyst increased bromide adsorption on the Pd catalyst. Optimization of the number of acid promoters is important as an excess of acid promoters was found to decrease hydrogen conversion by promoting the bromide adsorption at the less energetic sites.

TEM images of
a
Pd@SA(20),
b
Pd@SA(50),
c
Pd@SA(100), and
d
Pd@S [
37
]

Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using Pd@S and Pd@SA(X) catalysts (X = 20, 50 and 100) under different H
3
PO
4
concentrations and in the presence of Br
−
ions. Reaction conditions: T, 20 °C; P, 1 atm; time, 3 h; total flow rate, 22 mL/min; H
2
/O
2
, 1/10; reaction medium, 150 mL of DI water mixture (20 % ethanol, containing 0.9 mM KBr and 0, 0.01, 0.02 or 0.03 M H
3
PO
4
); weight of catalyst, 0.05 g [
37
]

Adsorption of Br
−
ions on Pd@S and Pd@SA(X) catalysts. Test conditions: 293 K, 1 atm, 0.2 g of catalyst, 20 mL of ethanol–water (4:1) mixture (containing 0.9 mM KBr and 0, 0.01, 0.02, or 0.03 M H
3
PO
4
), stirring rate = 1200 rpm, total gas flow rate = 0 or 22 mL/min, H
2
/O
2
= 1/10 (
v
/
v
), and adsorption time = 3 h [
37
]

Enhanced stability of the catalyst nanoparticles by adopting the core@shell structure is accompanied by restricted access of the reactant molecules to Pd surfaces. The core@shell structure encloses the catalyst nanoparticle, and the Pd area on which reactions can occur is reduced relative to the bare Pd catalyst. In order to overcome this limitation, a special type of a core@shell configuration, a core@void@shell structure, better known as a ‘yolk@shell,’ can be applied [
76
–
81
]. Lee’s group prepared yolk@shell nanocatalysts using a synthesis method described in Scheme
3
. The method consisted of the following four steps: (i) Pd nanoparticle synthesis; (ii) first encapsulation with SiO
2
to prepare Pd@SiO
2
; (iii) second encapsulation with ZrO
2
to prepare Pd@SiO
2
@ZrO
2
; and (iv) etching of the silica layer from Pd@SiO
2
@ZrO
2
with KOH solution. TEM images of the nanoparticles after each step are shown in Fig.
8
[
82
]. Compared to Pd@SiO
2
, the as-synthesized Pd@void@ZrO
2
catalyst has a 160 % increase in the exposed specific Pd surface area and a remarkable 120 % increase in hydrogen peroxide production [
82
].

TEM images of
a
Pd@SiO
2
,
b
Pd@SiO
2
@ZrO
2
, and
c
Pd@void@ZrO
2
and STEM image and EDX results (
inset
) of
d
Pd@void@ZrO
2
[
82
]

Application of nanotechnology to developing an effective catalyst for direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis is two-fold: (i) morphology and size control of the metal nanoparticles to enhance selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide formation, and (ii) immobilization of the as-synthesized nanocatalysts to minimize active metal loss during the reaction. Utilization of such approaches with Pd catalysts has improved the catalytic performance. To date, many studies have demonstrated superior catalytic performance (hydrogen peroxide yield and/or selectivity) of Pd-based alloys (Pd–Au, Pd–Pt, Pd–Ni, Pd–Sn, etc.) to that of monometallic Pd, but without critical morphology and size control [
83
–
86
]. For example, several DFT studies have also predicted the superior performance of the Pd–Au {111} facet to that of the monometallic Pd {111} [
42
,
43
], but there is no experimental evidence to support the simulation results. The synthesis and application of morphology- and size-controlled Pd-based bimetallic nanocatalysts to direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis remains a key research area for future studies. Another future research direction is the successful retention of the metal nanoparticle morphology during catalyst encapsulation into the core or yolk@shell structure. The nanoparticle immobilization methods discussed in this study (core@shell and yolk@shell) remove the surfactants via calcination, which causes a loss of the uniform nanoparticle morphology because of the high-temperature environment.
